title: SpaceX’s $17 Billion Spectrum Coup: Securing Starlink’s Direct-to-Cell Revolution
summary:
In a monumental transaction, SpaceX has allocated more than $17 billion—nearly equivalent to 75% of…
The post SpaceX’s $17 Billion Spectrum Coup: Securing Starlink’s Direct-to-Cell Revolution appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX has allocated more than $17 billion to secure exclusive radio spectrum rights from established satellite firm EchoStar. This strategic acquisition promises to lock in SpaceX’s preeminence in worldwide satellite communications for the foreseeable future. Equipped with its expansive satellite fleet and the forthcoming transition of Starship from its test program into an operational phase, SpaceX is primed to deploy vast network capabilities into low Earth orbit. The deal is worth $17 billion. It equips forthcoming Starlink Direct-to-Cell satellites with 20-fold throughput gains. This unlocks comprehensive 5G mobile service with performance akin to “comparable” ground-based LTE. Paired with earthly 5G setups, Starlink could vanquish all coverage gaps on the planet.

title: After early struggles, NASA’s ambitious mission to Titan is “on track” for launch
summary: "Probably the best part of my day is watching that team hit their milestones."
detailed_news: NASA's Dragonfly mission to fly across the surface of Titan is delayed and over budget. But the fault is due to the space agency's management rather than the program itself. The cost of the mission has soared from an initial figure of $850 million upon its selection in 2019 to $3.35 billion today. Dragonfly will explore impact craters where water may have existed in liquid form for thousands of years. Areas of Titan, in the wake of impacts, would be much like a primordial Earth when life started here billions of years ago. This will be NASA's first landing on another ocean world, with the primary objective of searching for the chemical building blocks of life.

title: NASA Partnerships Allow Artificial Intelligence to Predict Solar Events
summary: Exploring AI in space bolsters analytics software used in finance, manufacturing, and industry.
detailed_news: The Frontier Development Lab of Mountain View, California, is an ongoing partnership between NASA and commercial AI firms to apply advanced machine learning to problems that matter to the agency and beyond. The same solar activity that makes auroras can cause disruptions to satellites that are essential to systems on Earth. By importing several datasets monitoring the ionosphere, solar activity, and Earth’s magnetic field, the researchers were able to predict disruptive events 24 hours in advance.

Armstrong Operations and Checkout Building at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Monday, Aug. 11, 2025. […]
detailed_news: Artemis program will send astronauts to explore the Moon for scientific discovery, economic benefits, and to build the foundation for first crewed missions to Mars. Join the Artemis II mission and sign up to launch your name aboard the Orion spacecraft and SLS (Space Launch System) rocket alongside the crew.

title: Ami Choi: Unraveling the Invisible Universe
summary: Research Astrophysicist and Roman’s Deputy Wide Field Instrument Scientist – Goddard Space Flight Center From a young age, Ami Choi — now a research astrophysicist at NASA — was drawn to the vast and mysterious. By the fifth grade, she had narrowed her sights to two career paths: marine biology or astrophysics.  “I’ve always been […]
detailed_news: Ami Choi is a research astrophysicist at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center. She helped lay the groundwork for the Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope. Choi operates at the intersection of engineering, calibration, and cosmology. She's especially drawn to so-called systematics, which are effects that can alter signals. Choi encourages staying curious, being persistent, and taking opportunities to get involved in research. “You don’t have to be perfect at math or physics right away,” she said. ‘What matters most is a deep curiosity and the tenacity to keep pushing through.’

title: NASA Study: Celestial ‘Accident’ Sheds Light on Jupiter, Saturn Riddle
summary: An unusual cosmic object is helping scientists better understand the chemistry hidden deep in Jupiter and Saturn’s atmospheres — and potentially those of exoplanets. Why has silicon, one of the most common elements in the universe, gone largely undetected in the atmospheres of Jupiter, Saturn, and gas planets like them orbiting other stars? A new […]
detailed_news: The Accident is a brown dwarf, a ball of gas that’s not quite a planet and notquite a star. The Accident has a perplexing mix of physical features, some of which have been previously seen in only young brown dwarfs and others seen only in ancient ones. Among several surprises, they found evidence of a molecule they couldn’t initially identify. The study authors surmise it is because far less oxygen was present in the universe when the ancient brown dwarf formed. The available silicon would have bonded with hydrogen instead, resulting in silane. Brown dwarfs are often easier to study than gas giant exoplanets because the light from a faraway planet is typically drowned out by the star.

summary:

Prior to its Series A, the company’s most recent round was […]
The post Finnish Satellite Manufacturer ReOrbit Closes €45M Series A appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: Finnish satellite manufacturer ReOrbit has closed a €45 million Series A funding round. Part of the funding will be used to expand its manufacturing capacity. The round is one of the largest in the European space tech sector. It surpasses The Exploration Company’s €40 million series A and falls just short of Look Up’S €50 million round.

title: Crossroads to the Future – NASA Stennis Grows into a Model Federal City
summary: NASA’s Stennis Space Center is widely known for rocket propulsion testing, especially to support the NASA Artemis program to send astronauts to the Moon to prepare for future human exploration of Mars. What may not be so widely known is that the site also is a unique federal city, home to more than 50 federal, […]
detailed_news: NASA’s Stennis Space Center is widely known for rocket propulsion testing. The site is home to more than 50 federal, state, academic, and commercial tenants. It is also a model of government efficiency and a powerful economic engine for its region. “NASA Stennis is a remarkable story of vision and innovation,” Center Director John Bailey said. On June 14, 1974, NASA Administrator James Fletcher announced the south Mississippi location would be renamed National Space Technology Laboratories. There still were many developments to come, including the first space shuttle main engine test and the subsequent 34-year test campaign. However, even in this period of early development, one thing was clear – the future lay ahead and NASA Stennis was on its way.

title: Launch Your Name Around Moon in 2026 on NASA’s Artemis II Mission
summary: Lee este comunicado de prensa en español aquí. NASA is inviting the public to join the agency’s Artemis II test flight as four astronauts venture around the Moon and back to test systems and hardware needed for deep space exploration. As part of the agency’s “Send Your Name with Artemis II” effort, anyone can claim their […]
detailed_news: NASA is inviting the public to join the agency’s Artemis II test flight. Four astronauts will venture around the Moon and back to test systems and hardware needed for deep space exploration. Anyone can claim their spot by signing up before Jan. 21. The collected names will be put on an SD card loaded aboard Orion before launch.

title: NASA Stennis Provides Ideal Location for Range of Site Tenants
summary: If location, location, location is the overarching mantra in real estate, it is small wonder that NASA’s Stennis Space Center is considered a national asset and prime aerospace and technology operations site. It has long stood as a premier – and the nation’s largest – rocket propulsion test site. With unparalleled test infrastructure and expertise, […]
detailed_news: NASA’s Stennis Space Center is considered a prime aerospace and technology operations site. NASA Stennis is the choice location for a range of agencies, organizations, offices, and companies. For Relativity Space, the “unparalleled infrastructure” at NASA St Dennis has been key to enabling its rocket engine testing. The National Data Buoy Center was the very first NASA Stennis federal city tenant, arriving onsite in September 1970. Various Navy functions eventually located continuing operations onsite, including the Naval Meteorology and Oceanography Command, the Naval Oceanographic Office, and the Navy Office of Civilian Human Resources. The U.S. Department of Homeland Security credits the “high-quality, secure, and resilient” NASA St Dennis site for its decision to location information technology and applications operations on site.

title: Eye on the future, as SpaceX prepare Pad 2 and Block 3 at Starbase
summary:
As SpaceX prepares for Flight 11 of Starship, the company is also making significant strides…
The post Eye on the future, as SpaceX prepare Pad 2 and Block 3 at Starbase appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: As SpaceX prepares for Flight 11 of Starship, the company is also making significant strides at its Starbase facility in South Texas. Pad 2 at the launch site is edging closer to operational readiness, and the first Block 3 vehicle is set to fly from this pad on Flight 12. Engineers recently activated one of the gas generators that powers this high-pressure water system. Block 3: Pad 2 will debut SpaceX’s next generation of Starship design via the Block 3 upgrade. The launch tower still awaits a key element: the Ship Quick Disconnect Arm (SQD), currently under fabrication at a production site. Detailed imagery captured by NSF photographers reveals ongoing work around the chopsticks, where scaffolding remains extensive.  booster 18 is taking shape in Mega Bay 1, awaiting mating of its aft section to the LOX tank. By the time this section moves to Mega Bay 2 for further stacking, TPS application should be well underway. These developments illustrate SpaceX’s methodical progression toward Block 3, set to be the workhorse for the early phase of operational flights.

title: Life After Microgravity: Astronauts Reflect on Post-Flight Recovery
summary: Space changes you. It strengthens some muscles, weakens others, shifts fluids within your body, and realigns your sense of balance. NASA’s Human Research Program works to understand—and sometimes even counter—those changes so astronauts can thrive on future deep space missions.   Astronauts aboard the International Space Station work out roughly two hours a day to protect […]
detailed_news: Astronauts aboard the International Space Station work out roughly two hours a day to protect bone density, muscle strength and the cardiovascular system. The longer they are in microgravity, the harder it can be for the brain and body to readapt to gravity’s pull. Astronauts each recover on their own timetable and may encounter different challenges. NASA astronauts Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore returned from a nine-month mission with Crew-9 in early 2025. Williams said re-adapting to gravity can still be tough. Don Pettit, also a veteran flyer, came home in April 2025 after 220 days on the space station. Pettit said his recovery felt similar to earlier missions.

title: Life After Microgravity: Astronauts Reflect on Post-Flight Recovery
summary: Space changes you. It strengthens some muscles, weakens others, shifts fluids within your body, and realigns your sense of balance. detailed_news: Astronauts aboard the International Space Station work out roughly two hours a day to protect bone density, muscle strength and the cardiovascular system. The longer they are in microgravity, the harder it can be for the brain and body to readapt to gravity’s pull. Astronauts each recover on their own timetable and may encounter different challenges. NASA astronauts Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore returned from a nine-month mission with Crew-9 in early 2025. Williams said re-adapting to gravity can still be tough. Don Pettit, also a veteran flyer, came home in April 2025 after 220 days on the space station. Pettit said his recovery felt similar to earlier missions.

title: Perseverance Meets the Megabreccia
summary: Written by By Henry Manelski, Ph.D. student at Purdue University Last week, the Perseverance rover began an exciting new journey. Driving northwest of the Soroya ridge, Perseverance entered an area filled with a diverse range of boulders that the science team believes could hold clues to Mars’ early history. The terrain we are exploring is […]
detailed_news: Perseverance has entered an area filled with boulders that could hold clues to Mars’ early history. The terrain we are exploring is known as megabreccia : a chaotic mixture of broken rock fragments likely produced during ancient asteroid impacts. Some blocks may have originated in the gargantuan Isidis impact event, which created a 1,200-mile-wide crater just east of Jezero.

detailed_news: Falcon 9 booster B1078 will launch from Space Launch Complex 40 (SLC-40) at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station (CCSFS) in Florida. Two cargo resupply missions are set to launch to the International Space Station this week. In addition to Cygnus XL, Falcon 9 will launch one Starlink mission and two customer missions. Russia and China are also expected to launch satellite missions during the week.

title: NASA Sets Coverage for Northrop Grumman CRS-23, SpaceX Falcon 9 Launch
summary: NASA, Northrop Grumman, and SpaceX are targeting no earlier than 6:11 p.m. EDT, Sunday, Sept. 14, for the next launch to deliver science investigations, supplies, and equipment to the International Space Station. The mission is known as NASA’s Northrop Grumman Commercial Resupply Services 23, or Northrop Grumman CRS-23. Watch the agency’s launch and arrival coverage […]
detailed_news: The Northrop Grumman Cygnus XL spacecraft, carried on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket, will launch from Space Launch Complex 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida. This mission will be the first flight of the larger, more cargo-capable version of the company’s solar-powered spacecraft. Highlights of space station research and technology demonstrations include materials to produce semiconductor crystals in space. Watch, Engage on Social Media Let people know you’re watching the mission on X, Facebook, and Instagram by following and tagging these accounts. NASA’s virtual guest program for this mission also includes curated launch resources, notifications about related opportunities, and a stamp for the NASA virtual guest passport following launch.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch Indonesian communications satellite from Cape Canaveral
summary: The Nusantara Lima satellite is designed to augment communications in the region alongside Indonesia’s Satria satellite, which launched in June 2023. SpaceX is targeting liftoff from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Base at 8:02 p.m. EDT (0002 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX is targeting the liftoff of the N5 satellite from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral on Wednesday. The spacecraft comes from Satelit Nusantara Lima (SNL), a subsidiary of Indonesia’s first private satellite company. The satellite is built on the same Boeing-built bus used on Intelsat's IS-33e spacecraft, which suffered an anomaly in 2024. A computer-triggered abort halted the countdown of a Falcon 9 rocket Sunday at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The next mission in SpaceX's launch surge until at least Monday. The launch was visible across Southern California and as far away as Arizona as the booster climbed into sunlight at dusk.

title: NASA Astronaut Frank Rubio in Space Station Cupola
summary: NASA astronaut Frank Rubio poses for a picture in the International Space Station’s cupola on Oct. 1, 2022. Rubio was selected as a NASA astronaut in 2017. He trained as a flight engineer and member of the Expedition 68 crew. Rubio, along with cosmonauts Sergey Prokopyev and Dmitry Petelin of Roscosmos, launched Sept. 21, 2022, […]
detailed_news: Frank Rubio was selected as a NASA astronaut in 2017. Rubio, along with cosmonauts Sergey Prokopyev and Dmitry Petelin of Roscosmos, launched Sept. 21, 2022, on the Soyuz MS-22 spacecraft from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan to the space station. Rubio and his crewmates landed in Kazakhstan on Sept. 27, 2023.

title: Congress and Trump may compromise on the SLS rocket by axing its costly upper stage
summary: "At $4 billion a launch, you don’t have a Moon program."
detailed_news: NASA's Artemis Program and the future of the Space Launch System rocket are in the spotlight. The second Trump administration has sought to cancel the costly, expendable rocket. The solution involves canceling part of the SLS rocket now, but not all of it. The House Appropriations Committee will take up the Commerce, Justice, and Science budget bill on Wednesday morning. The House Appropriations Bill calls for NASA to "evaluate alternatives" to the Exploration Upper Stage. One of these is the Centaur V upper stage built by United Launch Alliance. Another option is a "short" version of the upper stage Blue Origin currently flies on its New Glenn rocket.

title: Starship Soars Back with Flight 10
summary: SpaceX’s Starship-Super Heavy launch vehicle completed its tenth flight test on Tuesday, August 26, 2025, marking this milestone with a resoundingly successful mission.
detailed_news: SpaceX’s Starship-Super Heavy launch vehicle completed its tenth flight test on Tuesday, August 26, 2025. Flight 10 breaks a streak of bad luck with the Block 2 or “V2” Starship design, which suffered three failures in a row on flights 7, 8, and 9. After ten all-up flights and more than two years, Starship has at last achieved all of the major objectives SpaceX sought to achieve. SpaceX aims to build and test the first V3 ships this year, though they may not fly until 2026. Meanwhile, Starship is still bound to its commitments to NASA and the Artemis program. Just over two years remain until Artemis III’s current public target of September 2027.

title: NASA Webb Looks at Earth-Sized, Habitable-Zone Exoplanet TRAPPIST-1 e
summary: Scientists are in the midst of observing the exoplanet TRAPPIST-1 e with NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope. Careful analysis of the results so far presents several potential scenarios for what the planet’s atmosphere and surface may be like, as NASA science missions lay key groundwork to answer the question, “are we alone in the universe?”  […]
detailed_news: Scientists are in the midst of observing the exoplanet TRAPPIST-1 e with NASA's James Webb Space Telescope. Careful analysis of the results so far presents several potential scenarios for what the planet’s atmosphere and surface may be like. NASA science missions lay key groundwork to answer the question “are we alone in the universe?” After previous Webb observations of planet b, scientists are fairly confident it is a bare rock without an atmosphere. The scientists are timing the observations so that Webb catches both planets b and e transiting the star one right after the other. Scientists plan to compare the data from both planets, and any indications of chemicals that show up only in planet e’s spectrum can be attributed to its atmosphere.

title: NASA Launches 2026 Lunabotics Challenge
summary: As college students across the country embark upon the academic year, NASA is giving them something else to look forward to – the agency’s 2026 Lunabotics Challenge. Teams interested in participating can submit their applications and supporting materials through NASA’s Stem Gateway portal beginning Monday, Sept. 8. Key dates and challenge details are available in […]
detailed_news: NASA is inviting teams to submit applications for its 2026 Lunabotics Challenge. Teams will create robots capable of building berms out of lunar regolith. Regolith will be important for blast protection during lunar landings and launches. The team scoring the most points will receive the Lunabotic Grand Prize.

title: Sending astronauts to the moon and Mars must be more than a photo op
summary:
The only way to create a sustainable program of exploring the moon and Mars with humans, beyond the initial flush of achievement, is by fully integrating science into our planning. title: EchoStar sells spectrum to SpaceX, cancels MDA satellite contract
summary:
